content:
Study in Taiwan: A 7-Step Guide for International Students

Introduction

Studying in Taiwan offers numerous opportunities for international students seeking quality education in a vibrant cultural environment. This guide presents a step-by-step approach to help prospective students navigate the application process effectively.

Step 1: Eligibility Assessment

Before proceeding with your application, ensure that you meet the eligibility criteria for international students as per the MOE Regulations Regarding International Students Undertaking Studies in Taiwan.

Step 2: Select Your University and Program

Research and choose a university program that aligns with your academic and career goals. Taiwan boasts high-quality educational institutions offering a diverse range of programs.

Step 3: Financial Planning

Plan your budget for tuition fees, living expenses, and other costs associated with studying abroad. Explore opportunities for international scholarships or part-time work to support your studies.

Step 4: Review Admission Requirements

Once you’ve identified your preferred university and program, carefully review the admission requirements and application deadlines. Each institution may have specific criteria and timelines for applications.

Step 5: Submit Your Application

Gather all necessary documentation and submit your application as per the requirements of your chosen study program and institution. Ensure that you adhere to deadlines and provide accurate information.

Step 6: Visa Application

Apply for a visitor or resident visa with the purpose of pursuing studies in Taiwan. Follow the visa application process outlined by the Taiwanese authorities and submit all required documents in a timely manner.

Step 7: Preparing for Departure

As you prepare to embark on your study journey in Taiwan, make necessary arrangements including:

  • Obtaining an Alien Resident Certificate
  • Securing appropriate insurance coverage
  • Arranging accommodation arrangements

Conclusion

By following these seven steps, international students can effectively prepare for and navigate the process of studying in Taiwan. Embrace the opportunities for academic and personal growth that Taiwan has to offer, and embark on a fulfilling educational journey in this dynamic and welcoming country.
description: A comprehensive guide outlining the steps to study in Taiwan for international students.
title: 7-Step Guide for International Students

content:
Education at a Glance

Taiwan has an outstanding higher education system that provides opportunities for international students to study a wide variety of subjects, ranging from Mandarin Chinese language and history to tropical agriculture and forestry, genetic engineering, business, semi-conductors, and more. In Taiwan, we hold education and scholarship in high regard, so you will experience a vibrant, modern society rooted in one of the worldâ€™s most fascinating cultures, and populated by some of the friendliest and most hospitable people in the world. We guarantee you a great education, which will lead you to a bright future!

10 Reasons to Study in Taiwan

  1. Academic Resources and Quality - 15.78%

Taiwan boasts excellent academic resources and quality, with world-class universities and research institutions offering diverse programs and cutting-edge facilities.

  1. Diverse Culture - 12.83%

Experience Taiwan’s rich and diverse culture, which blends traditional Chinese heritage with indigenous influences, creating a unique and vibrant environment for learning and exploration.

  1. Reasonable and Affordable Tuition - 11.25%

Enjoy reasonable and affordable tuition fees compared to other study destinations, making Taiwan an attractive option for students seeking high-quality education without breaking the bank.

  1. High-Standard Living Quality - 10.93%

Experience a high standard of living in Taiwan, with modern infrastructure, safe communities, and access to healthcare, transportation, and recreational amenities.

  1. Better Opportunity for Further Study - 10.89%

Taiwan offers better opportunities for further study, with pathways to advanced degrees and specialized training programs in various fields, enhancing your academic and professional development.

  1. Available Scholarship - 10.63%

Take advantage of available scholarships and financial aid options, including government-funded programs and university-specific awards, to support your academic journey in Taiwan.

  1. Learning Chinese - 10.05%

Immerse yourself in Mandarin Chinese language and culture, gaining valuable language skills that will enhance your global competitiveness and open doors to new opportunities in academia and beyond.

  1. Better Opportunity for Seeking Jobs - 7.71%

Benefit from Taiwan’s robust economy and job market, with opportunities for internships, part-time work, and post-graduate employment in diverse industries, including technology, finance, healthcare, and more.

  1. Location - 5.84%

Enjoy Taiwan’s strategic location in East Asia, offering easy access to neighboring countries and regions, as well as opportunities for cross-cultural exchange and collaboration.

  1. Others - 4.07%

Explore other unique aspects of studying in Taiwan, such as its beautiful natural landscapes, culinary delights, vibrant arts scene, and dynamic urban culture, enriching your overall educational experience.
description: Explore the reasons why Taiwan is an excellent destination for international students.
title: Education at a Glance 10 Reasons to Study in Taiwan

content:
Eligibility Requirements for International Students

Introduction

When applying for admission to universities in Taiwan as an international student, it’s crucial to understand the eligibility requirements and application procedures. This guide provides comprehensive information to help prospective students navigate the process.

Requirements Overview

There are various pathways to apply for admission, depending on the desired subject of study and the applicant’s background. It’s important to note that requirements and deadlines may differ between universities and degree programs.

Who is Considered an International Student?

To be classified as an international student in Taiwan, applicants must meet the following criteria:

  1. Foreign Nationality: Applicants must hold foreign nationality and have never previously studied in Taiwan as an overseas Chinese student.

  2. Not Admitted via Admission Placement: Applicants should not have been admitted through admission placement by the University Entrance Committee for Overseas Chinese students in the current application year.

  3. Compliance with Regulations: Applicants must adhere to the “Regulations Regarding International Students Undertaking Studies in Taiwan” established by the Ministry of Education.

Eligibility Check

Prospective international students who are unsure about their eligibility are encouraged to visit university websites such as National Taiwan University or National Chengchi University to conduct an eligibility check.

Academic Qualification Requirements

The academic qualification requirements for international applicants are as follows:

  • Undergraduate Programs: Applicants must hold a high school diploma.

  • Master’s Degree Programs: Applicants must possess a bachelor’s degree.

  • Ph.D. Programs: Applicants must have a master’s degree.

Conclusion

Understanding and meeting the eligibility requirements are essential steps for international students seeking admission to Taiwanese universities. By familiarizing themselves with the guidelines outlined in this document, prospective applicants can enhance their chances of a successful application process.

For further information and specific requirements, applicants are advised to consult the respective university websites and official guidelines.
description: Guidelines and requirements for international students applying to universities in Taiwan.
title: Eligibility Requirements for International Students Applying to Taiwanese Universities

content:
Q1: Am I eligible to apply as an international student?

You will be eligible as an international student if you fulfill the following 3 conditions:

  1. You have foreign nationality and have never studied in Taiwan before as an overseas Chinese student at the time of application.
  2. You have never been admitted through admission placement by the University Entrance Committee for Overseas Chinese Student at the time of application.
  3. You must apply in accordance with the “Regulations Regarding International Students Undertaking Studies in Taiwan” by the Ministry of Education (MOE).

Q2: How do I determine if I am an international student or an overseas Chinese student (including students from Hong Kong or Macao)?

Eligibility for applying for degree programs is slightly different between international students and overseas Chinese students.

International students:

If you meet the MOE Regulations Regarding International Students Undertaking Studies in Taiwan. If you hold foreign nationality and have never held Taiwanese nationality, and do not possess an overseas Chinese student status at the time of your application, you are qualified to apply for admission under this regulation.

Overseas Chinese students:

If you meet the MOE Regulations Regarding Study and Counseling Assistance for Overseas Chinese Students in Taiwan. The term “Overseas Chinese Student” refers to those who were born overseas and resided there until the present time of application or have stayed overseas for more than six consecutive years and have a permanent or long-term residence certificate.

Students from Hong Kong or Macao:

If you meet the MOE regulations regarding students from Hong Kong or Macao undertaking studies in Taiwan. If you have a permanent residence certificate issued by the governments of Hong Kong or Macao and have resided in Hong Kong, Macao, or another foreign country for more than six consecutive years, you are qualified to apply for undertaking studies in Taiwan.

Q3: If I meet the eligibility requirements for both international students and overseas Chinese students, which status should I use for the application?

If you meet both the eligibility of international students and overseas Chinese students, you can check your admission prospectus to decide which status you would like to choose. Please be aware that once you select a condition for admission, you cannot switch to another.

Generally, the differences between international students and overseas Chinese students are:

  • Tuitions: The tuitions for overseas Chinese students are the same as Taiwanese students. On the other hand, tuition for international students is usually 2 times that of Taiwanese students.
  • Scholarships: The scholarships for overseas Chinese students are usually available after the students are admitted. But the scholarships for international students usually require a prior application before the student comes to Taiwan.

Q4: May I apply for your degree program if my Chinese Language skills do not meet your requirements?

The situation depends on the program you are admitted to. If your program is taught mostly in English, your Chinese language skills will not be a problem for your study. However, many programs in Taiwan are still taught in Chinese only, so that will require higher Chinese language skills for you to follow the courses. We suggest you contact the international office and the program coordinator of your university regarding the language requirements.
description: Frequently Asked Questions for International Students Applying to Taiwan.
title: Frequently Asked Questions

content:
Higher Education System

Taiwan boasts an excellent global competitiveness despite limited natural resources. According to the World Competitiveness Yearbook 2019 published by the International Institute for Management Development (IMD) in Switzerland, Taiwan ranked 16th overall in global competitiveness among 63 countries, excelling in “Economic Performance” and “Business Efficiency Indices.” This economic prowess is attributed to Taiwan’s high-quality human resources, which are closely linked to the quality of its higher education system.

Brief Introduction

University/College and Graduate School Education

The maximum study period for university education (including universities, colleges, universities of technology, and technical colleges) is 4 years (the Post-bachelor Second Specialty Program is 1-2 years, while the bachelorâ€™s program is usually 2 years), and internships can last one-half to 2 years depending on the needs of the subject. For Masterâ€™s Degree candidates, the study period is limited to 1-4 years, and for Doctoral Degree candidates to 2-7 years.

Higher Education

Taiwanâ€™s higher education institutions include 2-year junior colleges, 5-year junior colleges, and 4-year universities. In 2019, Taiwan had 153 universities, colleges, and junior colleges serving over 1.24 million students. Reforms in teacher training have played an important part in the expansion of higher education, leading to significant improvements in teacher quality. Currently, Ph.D. degree holders account for over 80% of faculty in Taiwan universities.

To maintain competitiveness, Taiwanâ€™s government has invested more than US$8 billion in higher education annually in the last five years to encourage universities to enhance their standards for research and teaching, with remarkable results. Although tuition remains reasonable, the Ministry of Education and several universities jointly established the Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation Council of Taiwan in 2005 to regularly evaluate universities in terms of faculty quality, teaching, research, and service.

Higher Technological and Vocational Education

Institutes of technology and universities of science and technology, established in accordance with the provisions of the University Act, aim to train individuals with high-level professional and practical work skills. These institutions offer associate’s degree programs, bachelor’s degree programs, master’s degree programs, and doctoral degree programs.

The curriculum is credit-based, with students in a four-year program required to complete 128 credit-hours, while those in two-year bachelor’s degree programs must complete 72 credit hours before graduation. Professional master’s degree programs require completion of 24 credit hours and submission of a master’s thesis, while doctoral programs demand at least 18 credit hours and submission of a doctoral dissertation.

Taiwan has also made significant achievements in innovation, ranking 4th for innovation among 141 countries in 2019 according to the World Economic Forum. The research and instruction taking place in Taiwanâ€™s universities have created a critical mass of innovation and creativity, consistently recognized in international design competitions.
description: Explore Taiwan's higher education system and its contribution to global competitiveness.
title: Higher Education System in Taiwan

content:
Where is Taiwan?

Taiwan and its surrounding islands are situated in East Asia at the northwestern edge of the Pacific Ocean. It possesses an endless variety of terrains, forests, agricultural products, and marine ecologies, as well as a diversity of ethnic cultures along with enchanting human customs and practices.

Location:

Taiwan is located off the eastern and southeastern coasts of the Asian continent, between Japan and the Philippines. It measures approximately 400 kilometers from north to south and around 145 kilometers from east to west at its widest.

Major Cities

Taipei

Taipei City, the capital of Taiwan, is located in northern Taiwan and has a population of nearly 2.7 million. It is the political, economic, and cultural center of Taiwan.

  • Find Universities in Taipei

New Taipei City

Surrounding the countryâ€™s capital, New Taipei City covers an area of just over 2000 square kilometers and has a population of over 3.9 million. Its proximity to Taipei has helped New Taipei City develop as a major concentration of industry and commerce.

  • Find Universities in New Taipei City

Taoyuan

Taoyuan city lies west of New Taipei City and is Taiwanâ€™s fourth-largest city. It serves as Taiwanâ€™s key gateway to the outside world, hosting the country’s largest international airport.

  • Find Universities in Taoyuan

Taichung

Taichung, the largest city of central Taiwan, is known as â€˜the center of Taiwanâ€™. It serves as an essential economic and transport hub, linking industry and agriculture in Taiwanâ€™s central region.

  • Find Universities in Taichung

Tainan

Established in 1624, Tainan is Taiwanâ€™s oldest city and is famous for its rich history, culture, architecture, and heritage sites.

  • Find Universities in Tainan

Kaohsiung

Kaohsiung, Taiwanâ€™s second-largest city, is a thriving metropolis spread over nearly 3000 square kilometers. It serves as a critical artery for Asia-Pacific trade and commerce.

  • Find Universities in Kaohsiung

Climate

Taiwan has a long summer and a short, mild winter, with varied climate zones across the island.

  • The mean temperature ranges from around 18Â°C in winter to 29Â°C in summer.
  • Annual rainfall is approximately 2,600 millimeters, with regional variations.
  • Taiwan experiences typhoons from July to September, with some causing severe damage but also contributing to the islandâ€™s water resources.

Natural Environment

Geography

Taiwan covers an area of approximately 36,000 square kilometers and is characterized by forested mountains, hills, plains, and coastal areas. The Central Mountain Range runs from north to south, with the Yushan Range containing Taiwanâ€™s highest peak.

Mountains

Taiwan has over 200 peaks that are more than 3,000 meters high, making it geographically unique. The island is home to nine national parks, each offering distinct topographic landscapes.

  • Taiwan Tourism Bureau
  • Yushan National Park
  • Yangmingshan National Park
  • Taroko National Park
  • Shei-Pa National Park

Sea World

Taiwanâ€™s marine ecology is vibrant, with diverse marine life and stunning coral reefs.

  • Kenting National Park
  • Marine National Park

Eco-Landscape

Taiwan’s warm and humid climate supports abundant animal and plant life, making it a haven for eco-tourism.

  • Ecotourism Recommendation

Culture and Language

Taiwan is an important center for Buddhism, Taoism, literature, arts, and crafts, with a unique Taiwanese culture that incorporates various features of Chinese culture.

  • Taiwanese Indigenous Peoples

Economic Strength

Taiwan plays an influential role in the global economy, particularly in the information and communications technology (ICT) industry.

  • Ministry of Education (MOE)
  • Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA)

Science and Technology

Taiwan is a leading technology powerhouse, with significant contributions from both the public and private sectors.

  • Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Ltd. (TSMC)
  • Foxconn Technology Group

Cuisine

Taiwanese cuisine is diverse and unforgettable, with unique dishes that have gained worldwide attention.

  • Explore Taiwanese Cuisine

Transportation

Taiwan has a convenient and safe transport network, including modern metro systems, high-speed rail, and bicycle rental services.

  • Taipei Metro
  • Kaohsiung Metro
  • Taiwan High Speed Rail
  • uBike Bicycle Rental
description: Explore the quick facts about Taiwan, from its geography to culture and economic strength.
title: Quick Facts About Taiwan

content:
GOVERNMENT SCHOLARSHIP

The Taiwan Fellowships & Scholarships (TAFS) program is a Republic of China (R.O.C.) government initiative aimed to promote relevant research, educational links, and enduring friendships between Taiwan and the global community.

The TAFS comprises 8 awards in 3 categories: Fellowships for research, Huayu (Mandarin) Enrichment Scholarships, and Scholarships for Degree. Approximately 1,200 grants are provided annually for undergraduate and postgraduate students as well as researchers across the world to study or to conduct advanced research in Taiwan.

For more information, please visit the respective website of each award or contact the R.O.C. embassy or representative office near you.

FOR DEGREE

  • Government Scholarships

    • MOE Taiwan Scholarship
      • Status: BA / MS / PhD

  • Government Scholarships

    • MOFA Taiwan Scholarship
      • Status: BA / MS / PhD

  • Private-sector Scholarships

    • Academia Sinica Taiwan International Graduate Program
      • Status: PhD

  • Government Scholarships

    • TaiwanICDF International Higher Education Scholarship
      • Status: BA / MS / PhD

  • Government Scholarships

    • Elite Study in Taiwan
      • Status: BA / MS / PhD
description: Overview of Taiwan Fellowships & Scholarships program.
title: Taiwan Fellowships & Scholarships

content:
Services for Students Pursuing Higher Studies in Taiwan

Are you considering pursuing your bachelor’s, master’s, or Ph.D. studies in Taiwan? We offer comprehensive services tailored to your needs and aimed at making your transition to Taiwanese universities seamless and efficient.

STEP 1: Initial Consultation

In this step, we provide you with valuable insights into the current conditions in Taiwan and assess your specific requirements. Through an audio/video call, we discuss your aspirations and concerns, offering personalized advice to kickstart your journey.

Service Fee:

  • â‚¹1000 INR / ~400 NTD (Equivalent to 6 Cups of Coffee in FamilyMart)

STEP 2: Application Guidance

Once you’ve successfully completed Step 1, we equip you with the knowledge and tools necessary to navigate the application process independently. We’ll guide you through the intricacies of the application procedures, empowering you to apply with confidence and save significant costs along the way.

Service Fee:

  • â‚¹20,000 INR

STEP 3: Comprehensive Admission Assistance

For those seeking hands-on support throughout the admission process, our team offers comprehensive guidance at every stage. From application submission to document preparation and beyond, we’ll be by your side, ensuring a smooth and successful admission experience.

Service Fee:

  • â‚¹40,000 INR

Payment Options

Indian Students

Indian students can conveniently make payments using any UPI app.

International Students (excluding India)

International students are encouraged to utilize PayPal for secure and hassle-free transactions.

Embark on your educational journey in Taiwan with confidence, knowing that our dedicated team is here to support you every step of the way. Get in touch today to explore how we can help you achieve your academic goals.
description: Services for Students Pursuing Higher Studies in Taiwan
title: Services for Students Pursuing Higher Studies in Taiwan

content:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.
title: Hello R Markdown
